verses.text: Then he made an altar of bronze, twenty cubits long, twenty cubits wide, and ten cubits high.
verses.comment: The Hebrew cubit is about 18 inches or 45 centimeters.

verses.text: Also, he made the sea of cast metal. It was round, ten cubits from rim to rim, five cubits high, and a line of thirty cubits measured around it.
verses.comment: The 'sea' is a large basin for washing used by the priests.

verses.text: Under it were figures of gourds, encircling it, ten to a cubit, surrounding the sea all around. The gourds were cast in two rows when it was cast.
verses.comment: The translation harmonizes the description of the 'gourds' (lions or oxen in some versions); here, 'gourds' is used per original Hebrew.

verses.text: It stood on twelve oxen, three facing north, three facing west, three facing south, and three facing east. The sea was set on top of them, and all their hindquarters were toward the center.
verses.comment: Direction of the oxen is clarified as per the Hebrew.

verses.text: Its thickness was a handbreadth. Its rim was made like the rim of a cup, like a lily blossom. It held three thousand baths.
verses.comment: A bath is about 22 liters or 5.8 gallons; Chronicles gives 3,000, while 1 Kings mentions 2,000.

verses.text: He also made ten basins and set five on the right side and five on the left to wash in them. They rinsed what was used for the burnt offerings there, but the sea was for the priests to wash in.
verses.comment: 'Basins' are washing vessels for cleansing sacrificial parts.

verses.text: He made ten lampstands of gold as prescribed, and set them in the temple, five on the right side and five on the left.
He made ten tables and placed them in the temple, five on the right side and five on the left. He also made a hundred bowls of gold.
verses.comment: The 'bowls' are likely for the drink offerings.

verses.text: He made the court of the priests, and the great court, and doors for the court, and overlaid their doors with bronze.
He set the sea on the right side of the temple, toward the southeast.
verses.comment: 'Right side' is from the perspective of facing the temple.

verses.text: And Huram made the pots, the shovels, and the bowls. So Huram completed the work he did for King Solomon on Godâ€™s house:
verses.comment: 'Huram' is the skilled craftsman from Tyre.

verses.text: the two pillars, the bowls, and the two capitals on top of the pillars; the two latticeworks to cover the two bowls of the capitals which were on top of the pillars;
the four hundred pomegranates for the two latticeworks, two rows of pomegranates for each latticework to cover the two bowls of the capitals that were on the pillars.
He also made stands and the basins on the stands,
the one sea and the twelve oxen under it,
as well as the pots, the shovels, the forks, and all their related objects. Huram-abi made these for King Solomon for the house of the Lord, out of polished bronze.
The king cast them in the plain of the Jordan, in the clay ground between Succoth and Zeredah.
verses.comment: 'Cast' refers to the process of pouring molten metal into molds.

verses.text: Solomon made all these objects in great abundance, so much that the weight of the bronze could not be determined.
verses.comment: The text emphasizes the vast quantity of bronze used.

verses.text: So Solomon made all the items that were in the house of God: the golden altar, the tables on which the bread of the Presence was set,
the lampstands of pure gold with their lamps, to burn as prescribed in front of the inner sanctuary,
the flowers, the lamps, and the tongs of gold, of purest gold;

the snuffers, the bowls, the dishes for incense, and the firepans, of pure gold, and the entrance to the house: its inner doors for the Most Holy Place, and the doors of the nave of the temple, were of gold.
verses.comment: 'Most Holy Place' is a standard term for the innermost sanctuary.
